title: Rolando Zárate
text:
Rolando David Zárate Riga (born 6 August 1978) is an Argentine former professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="centre%20forward">centre forward</a>, and is a <a href="sports%20agent">sports agent</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Haedo%2C%20Buenos%20Aires%20Province">Haedo, Buenos Aires Province</a>, Zárate spent most of his career for <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20Sarsfield">Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield</a>, representing the club in two different spells. He made his professional debut in 1997, playing in only 17 <a href="Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Primera División</a> games in his first two seasons combined.
Zárate moved to Spain in 1998, going on to remain in that country for the following four years, always on loan: he started out at <a href="Terrassa%20FC">Terrassa FC</a> in the <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">third division</a>, joining <a href="Real%20Madrid%20Castilla">Real Madrid Castilla</a> in the same level the following year. His impressive scoring form prompted <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a> boss <a href="Vicente%20del%20Bosque">Vicente del Bosque</a> to promote him to the main squad, and he scored three official goals for them (one in <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> and two in the <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey">Copa del Rey</a>); between 2001 and 2002 he represented <a href="Ciudad%20de%20Murcia">Ciudad de Murcia</a> and its neighbours <a href="Real%20Murcia">Real Murcia</a>, respectively in divisions three and <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">two</a>.
Zárate played with <a href="Livingston%20F.C.">Livingston</a> in the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Scottish%20Premier%20League">2002–03 season</a>, still owned by Vélez. He netted twice on his debut in the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">Scottish Premier League</a>, a 3–2 home win against <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a>, and eventually proved instrumental as the "Livi Lions" retained their division status.
Zárate's last loan would be with <a href="Ittihad%20FC">Ittihad FC</a> in Saudi Arabia. Again with Vélez, he scored 13 times in the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20in%20Argentine%20football">2004 Clausura Tournament</a>, adding eight in <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20in%20Argentine%20football">the following year's Apertura</a>. In the subsequent <a href="Apertura%20and%20Clausura">Clausura</a>, "Roly" netted seven goals as his team won the national championship for the first time in seven years.
In the following years, Zárate played in Mexico for two teams, also representing <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20River%20Plate">Club Atlético River Plate</a> without any impact. On 25 July 2009, he re-signed with Vélez on a <a href="Free%20transfer%20%28association%20football%29">free transfer</a> after a period of trial, from Ecuador's <a href="Barcelona%20Sporting%20Club">Barcelona Sporting Club</a>, but was released during that year due to injury to his <a href="spinal%20cord">spinal cord</a>; he returned to training in early 2010 and, eventually, signed a new one-year deal.
For <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20season">2010–11</a>, 32-year-old Zárate joined <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Hurac%C3%A1n">Club Atlético Huracán</a> in the top flight, for free. At the end of the campaign, the side were tied with <a href="Gimnasia%20y%20Esgrima%20de%20La%20Plata">Gimnasia y Esgrima de La Plata</a> for the second-to-last position in the relegation ranking, and thus needed to play a tiebreaker, losing it 2–0.
Following Huracán's relegation, Zárate's contract at the <a href="Parque%20Patricios">Parque Patricios</a> ended and he signed with another club in the <a href="Primera%20B%20Nacional">second division</a>, <a href="Defensa%20y%20Justicia">Defensa y Justicia</a>, again on a free transfer. After his retirement he became a <a href="Sports%20agent">football agent</a>, representing <a href="Maximiliano%20Romero">Maximiliano Romero</a> among others and arranging his December 2017 transfer of Romero from Vélez to <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a>.
International career.
Zárate made his debut for <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a> on 9 March 2005, a <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly match</a> with <a href="Mexico%20national%20football%20team">Mexico</a> in which the former only fielded players from the domestic league. He scored in a 1–1 draw, in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.
Also in that year, Zárate made his second and last appearance, playing 15 minutes in a 2–1 win in <a href="Bolivia%20national%20football%20team">Bolivia</a> for the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a> <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28CONMEBOL%29">qualifiers</a>.
Personal life.
Zárate has three brothers, all footballers: younger <a href="Mauro%20Z%C3%A1rate">Mauro</a> and older <a href="Sergio%20Z%C3%A1rate">Sergio</a> and <a href="Ariel%20Z%C3%A1rate">Ariel</a>, with the first two eventually representing the Argentina national team. Rolando's son, <a href="Tob%C3%ADas%20Z%C3%A1rate">Tobías</a>, also became a professional footballer.
